The ceasefire in Syria has entered its third day at this point. There has been significant Russian military buildup regarding ground troops as well as naval forces and air forces. Meanwhile the secretary-general of NATO states that "there are no plans about NATO providing ground troops for the military operations in Syria." France was the country that specifically asked for the task force overseeing the cessation of hostilities meet immediately. He also asked that the UN Security Council take those guilty of violations in Syria to the International Criminal Court. If anything I think that France is looking to de-escalate involvement.

While news reports show that France has been aggressively pursuing ISIS in Libya, it is unlikely to get further involved in Iraq and Syria without the support of NATO allies, namely the US, which has consistently expressed that it will not deploy "boots on the ground" to fight ISIS. France used air power to target ISIS following the latest terrorist attacks against it, and barring further escalation, there is no reason to think it will go it alone in the next months. C- compare to response to previous terror attacks, response in Libya, H- statements by French officials, K- preferences of NATO leaders not to be involved in another ground war, N: UN Security Council politics, particularly Russian support of Syrian state sovereignty, preclude the international coalition likely to accompany French ground troops.

Russian airstrikes have made the Syrian part of this question moot, at least during the forecasting period. No EU member in its collective right mind would put troops on the ground where they stood a reasonable chance (anything over zero) of becoming subject to one of Vladimir's "mistakes." It is also clear that Russia intends to tip the balance around Aleppo, partitioning Syria into "our boy" and "the other side's problem." That leaves the West with no clear entry to IS controlled territory except via Turkey, which is getting into the fray to blunt the advance of the Kurds. The U.S. is already mired in Iraq; no further involvement there is needed. Expect western military attention to shift to Libya to a greater extent than it already has. That unguarded Mediterranean coastline provides a far simpler approach.

Top Canadian General compares Canadian involvement in Iraq to peace mission!
“A political truth can sometimes be different.”
http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/top-soldier-defends-iraq-mission-as-non-combat-says-hes-expert-on-what-is-combat You can't be conducting a peace mission while simultaneously being "a hostile party to an armed conflict!" Each country, it seems, has a slightly different spin on the same general issue: failure to tell the truth as to troop involvement in Syria and Iraq. For Canada, they have seemingly hung their hat on "combat mission" as being their political communication "defeat-device" of choice. It's the increasingly frayed and tattered Canadian variant of the "boots on the ground" kabuki, and it's still on show in the western government capital nearest to you. It keeps raising its repudiated head. “I’m the expert on what is combat and what is not.” Well, if that is true, then they'd better find another general to command Canadian forces immediately! They should be looking for someone who is an expert "in" combat, not an expert on "what is" combat. Bottom line: The Liberal government of Canada has reneged upon their pledge to "end Canada’s combat mission in Iraq and Syria." This they have not done, but have instead escalated it. And this is the point, so long as the press allows the issue to remain a discussion of the Yes/No aspect of a deceptively-employed definition, the more relevant issue of the escalation continues inadequately addressed.  There is the much broader, and far more important, issue of basic competency with those who, for political expediency or otherwise, employ such semantic defeat-devices. There must be a reason that explains the discrepancy between use of the lie and use of the truth in political communication. Personally, I think it's a surprisingly successful method of escaping accountability as to the magnitude of a policy. If the discussion remains centered on whether the policy is true or not, the issue of the magnitude or extent of the policy remains neglected. What's interesting, is that this "cost of deception benefit," the cost that those who do this kabuki dance are willing to pay to achieve the benefit they seek by employing deception is diffused and borne by the entire political system. Each and every Canadian citizen that recognizes the defeat-device for what it is loses respect for the entire Canadian government just one bit (more). They are trading trust in government generally away for what? An ability to escape accountability on troop escalation? This is not a good trade, and therefore their competence as leaders is called into question. It'd be better to say something along the lines of: the situation has changed, we see ISIS on the verge of collapse, and we believe Canadian troops can help make the difference in ending this tragedy that has dragged on far too long already. OK, great. So how many troops are we talking about? “They’re increasing the combat role”
"the total number of Canadian military personnel, including a logistics base in Kuwait, additional advisers and officers in Baghdad, will grow to at least 830 from the current level of about 650"
http://www.hilltimes.com/news/2016/02/19/uss-positive-tweets-on-canadas-new-mission-against-isil-show-feds-increasing-combat-role/45339 This ongoing mission and the country it represents would benefit from increased transparency.
http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/opinion/analysis/is-it-combat-or-not-369518412.html My point exactly. Calling into question the credibility of the entire government for the simple purpose of obfuscating some basic facts is a very, very crappy trade-off. It calls into question the competency of the leadership. I commend these Canadian journalists for at least doing their best in trying to ask the right questions. "Clinton Says No Combat Troops, But Special Forces OK in Syria and Iraq"
http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/morning-defense/2016/02/saudi-arabia-offers-path-for-ground-troops-in-syria-clinton-hits-sanders-on-foreign-policy-congress-pentagon-feud-over-russian-rocket-engine-replacement-212551 — CLINTON SAYS NO COMBAT TROOPS, BUT SPECIAL FORCES OK IN SYRIA AND IRAQ: “Hillary Clinton looks like she split hairs a bit too much when asked about President Obama’s moves to increase the number of U.S. military forces headed to Middle East hotspots,” reports POLITICO’s Darren Samuelsohn: “‘I am against American combat troops being in Syria and Iraq,’ she said, before noting in her very next breath: ‘I support special forces.’ But the special operation forces on the ground there are very much engaged in fighting ISIS. ‘A raid is a combat operation, there’s no way around that,’ Col. Steve Warren, a U.S. military spokesman based in Baghdad, said in December as 100 more military members joined the 3,500 already in Iraq.” Kudos to the reporters from Politico for calling Clinton out on the semantic infraction. While "splitting hairs" may not be how I would describe it, it is better than saying nothing. Often it takes time and reflection to be able to fully articulate why there is a visceral reaction to a semantic infraction. I don't think they have a strong analysis of the fault, but they get credit for calling out the violation and at least trying to offer an explanation. Holding the line on "combat troops" is necessary to move forward to tackle the other semantic infraction of "boots on the ground," a phrase also contrary to good reasoning. At some point I really do believe that such abuses of language will be recognized for what they are; viz., a measure of disrespect and disdain for the listener by the speaker. It's just as if the speaker moved to the center of a crowded room and intentionally "cut gas" as loud and obnoxiously as they could. Sure, he/she had it "in their power" to do so. But it's an infringement upon the good taste of the entire room. It is the foisting of semantic confusion upon the group that while able to be rejected by those so-inclined to reflect upon it, places an unnecessary cognitive burden upon the entire group. It is saying, in effect, "I do not care about your ability to reason correctly in your life," and as demonstration of this "I will place this semantic object as an obstacle to your good reasoning." It's just very poor taste and very bad manners by someone. It's a semantic attack no less.

I suggested that  since GJI is acknowledging that it is creating some fuzzy questions, how about allowing us to make fuzzy forecasts on those questions? +8 based on links & analyses of @Clairvoyance & @aaseawaf15.  We have a two-step forecast: 1) Will the troops be deployed? and, if so 2) Will deployment be credibly reported? Because I believe the coalition is building to a major offensive campaign (which I also believe focuses the French upon Syria), and I believe the "best practice" is always to allow a period of reconnaissance, intelligence gathering, and acclimation, I have been leaning towards "Yes" as to the first part of the two-step process. [Edit: And for those who suggest that French SF may have already been there, I would suggest an increased tempo and scope as to their activities.] I could place some probability on the first step, but taking Le Drian's "hint" as a confirmation, and for computational simplicity, I'm just going to assume it to be "yes." The aforementioned is just a long way of saying we are faced with forecasting the probability that these (assumed to be) deployed troops will be reported upon. This is challenging because, except for very rare glimpses, it is a controlled information environment.
- French "long-standing policy of never discussing the deployment of its elite troops." Certainly an excellent operational security policy and one that would likely be respected by the vast majority of Western news sources and outlets.
+ The assumption that LeDrian is sophisticated enough to recognize that even a "hint" is a violation of that policy, which therefore requires the additional assumption that LeDrian had some sufficient reason to violate that policy. Would the desire to generate a signal of coalition solidarity be sufficient reason? Is there some perceived need to demonstrate some active effort to a domestic audience? Perhaps this reason, whatever it may be, will continue.
+ There are some reputable non-Western sources and outlets who may have an independent interest in the report; which can only now be enhanced by, perhaps, the professional ambition of some intrepid journalist to pop the "hint" bubble that Le Drian has created.
- The nature of the activities are covert, often in "the dark" both figuratively and literally. Not a lot of free-floating witnesses who don't have their back turned to the action as they are running away. Also, maybe the "hint" indicates the French SF are embedded within some U.S. SF group(s), making distinctive identification difficult.
+/- The one perhaps relevant incident we have is that of a Canadian special force contingent. No news was generated by this contingent until they were placed under a crazy banzai-like attack (my description) by ISIL. If ISIL really is feeling the pressure, it is possible the frequency of such "crazy" attacks might increase, thus perhaps drawing attention to a French SF contingent. I don't think we can count on any "random" reporter or event to deliver a confirmation. I'm willing to continue to ride high on this, however, because I'm thinking that whatever the reason Le Drian had to break silence, may continue to exist in the future. There are all possible reasons. Maybe a trial balloon to get the feel for the reaction of the French public. Maybe a message to allies that France is doing their part and they should step up. Maybe a signal to Russia and Iran that they are "publicly" committed (although I'm sure the Russians and Iranians already knew if they were covertly committed). In short, it's very risky to be forecasting a strong "yes" on the second step. The situation is very far from being able to say "If they're there, they will be found out and publicly reported."

This question implies deploying combat troops to fight but does not seem to require actual combat.  Given the strong reaction to the Paris attacks and subsequent ISIS linked activity elsewhere and given that the French Government has already deployed significant resources for their air attacks, this question suggests that deployment of combat troops could well be expected within the time frame.

Although France would be a formidable enemy for ISIS to face on the battlefield, the overall pacifist movement of France will preclude direct action for the time being. Evoking the mutual protection clause of the European Charter was a good first step and the roundup of terror suspects, weapons and intelligence bodes well for France to halt future attacks, there isn't enough anger among the other countries of Europe yet to deploy troops beyond those of France and England. If France evoked Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, it would be a different story. The US may not want to get involved directly, but we could supply needed logistical assistance to NATO troops.

President Hollande did two specific things in the wake of the Paris attacks: 1.	Invoked the “mutual assistance clause” of the Treaty on the European Union
2.	Declared a state of emergency in France for 3 months By invoking article 42.7, Hollande signaled that Paris believes the terrorism challenge must be met by key members of the European Union. The French military and the French budget were stretched prior to the Paris attacks. The French military is operating in various parts of the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa. In order for the French to increase their military engagements in the Syrian conflict and secure its own population, Hollande made clear that the European Union’s “security pact now prevails over the stability pact.” In parallel, Hollande announced that French defense reductions would be cancelled until 2019. By cancelling the defense reductions, France will likely violate the European Union’s budgetary rules. (Given the recent Greek budget crisis, there seems to be some sort of irony here.)
Prior to setting any further ground operations in motion, France needs other members of the European Union to share some of the burden and the costs of security. Unfortunately, given the migrant crisis in Europe, along with disagreements among member states about security obligations, it seems unlikely France will receive the relief it seeks anytime soon. Therefore, Hollande's declaration of "war" does not appear to include the deployment of combat troops in either Syria or Iraq.  The probability of a “yes” outcome here seems low.  What would lead to a “yes?” outcome:  1.	Another ISIS attack on French soil and/or an attack on a key ally or EU member state In broad terms, by invoking Article 42.7, Hollande seeks to build a EU coalition sympathetic to its aims which include: sharing the cost of counter-terrorism within the borders of the EU, expanded intelligence among member states, receiving military relief from member states for various global operations, and establishing a leadership role in designing a diplomatic solution for the Syrian Civil war. As many experts believe, the defeat of ISIS is contingent on finding a political solution in Syria. In terms of Iraq, unless the Iraqi government extends an invitation to France to bring ground troops onto its territory, any such French deployment would not be considered based on issues of sovereignty.   I don’t see how analyzing previous French military engagements (in terms of how many over X number of years) takes us very far in establishing a probability for this question. For one thing, history does play a role in each decision to engage military ground operations on foreign soil. The nature of each military engagement differs based on its unique historical context.  Therefore, it’s difficult to calculate estimates of the probability of future military engagements based on data from previous decades.  Moreover, The French colonial wars of the 20th century included a failed attempt to keep Syria under its power. It should be remembered it took 10 years after a negotiated settlement for Syrian nationalists to force the evacuation of French troops from Syria. That was 1946. If Hollande were to send French forces to fight on Syrian soil, these remembrances would likely be used as evidence of the West’s penchant for colonial reprises. Regardless of the fact that such an accusation has little merit, the charge fits in with a narrative conducive to extremist ideology (ISIS).  All that said, at this point, the likelihood of the French sending troops into Syria or Iraq seems unlikely in the short term. As other commentators have noted, with another attack on French or European soil, the probability would very likely go in the other direction very quickly.  Like the situation in Europe, the question requires constant vigilance in deciding the final outcome.
